Title: Comparison of the efferents of the amygdala and the hippocampal formation in the rhesus monkey: II. Reciprocal and non-reciprocal connections
Abstract: The pattern of direct connections between the amygdala and the hippocampal formation in the rhesus monkey (Macaca mulatta) was delineated by using both anterograde and retrograde tract-tracing techniques. From the amygdala the accessory basal, medial basal, and the cortical nuclei and the cortical amygdaloid transition area send projections to the hippocampal formation. The efferents from the magnocellular part of the accessory basal nucleus and the cortical nuclei terminate in the molecular layer of subfields CA3, CA2, and CA1', and to a lesser extent in the molecular layer and the superficial part of the pyramidal cell layers of the prosubiculum. In contrast, the projections from the medial basal nucleus and the cortical amygdaloid transition area terminate in the molecular layer and the superficial part of the pyramidal cell layers of the prosubiculum only. From the hippocampal formation, subfield CA1' and the prosubiculum send efferents that terminate in the medial basal nucleus, the cortical transition area, and the ventral part of the cortical nuclei. In addition, the CA1' subfield projects to the ventral, parvicellular part of the accessory basal nucleus. The present data emphasize an important role for the prosubiculum and the CA1' subfield in medial temporal lobe area connections. Both regions, in addition to supporting direct connections between the amygdala and the hippocampal formation, also have extensive connections with the entorhinal cortex. As for the amygdala, the accessory basal nucleus sends efferents to both the hippocampal formation and the entorhinal cortex. The data demonstrate an anatomical means by which the amygdala, hippocampal formation, and the entorhinal cortex may interact. It is proposed that these connections may be important in the limbic memory system.

@BrainMaps_Delineation.Region_Parcellation: Hippocampal formation, entorhinal cortex, prosubiculum, amygdala
@BrainMaps_Delineation.Comments: The authors explicitly state which parcellation scheme they follow, but they delineate the areas by their own cytoarchitectonic analyses.

@BrainMaps_UnspecificAdoption.Comments: Areas TF and TH have been used in this paper without any information in the text or figures whether these areas are delineated by the authors or whether theses areas are adopted by them.

"Amygdaloid complex. The nomenclature applied to the primate amygdala in this investigation was derived from the reports of Crosby and Humphrey ('41) and Lauer ('45). A detailed description was presented in the previous report (Saunders and Rosene, '88)." (p. 188)

"Hippocampal formation. The nomenclature applied to the different subdivisions and levels of the primate hippocampal formation was derived from that of Lorente de No´ ('34), described in the previous report (Saunders and Rosene, '88), and is more fully illustrated elsewhere (Rosene and Van Hoesen, '87). The term "hippocampal formation" refers to the three- layered allocortex of the dentate gyrus, the Ammonic subfields CA1, CA2, CA3, and CA4, the prosubiculum, (ProS), and the subiculum (Sub). …Two subdivisions need further description because they figure prominently in the present results and have not been adequately described previously. These regions are the prosubiculum, and a region in the medial and dorsal part of the genu which we have termed CA1´." (p. 188)

"Hippocampal formation. @InterMapRelations.Comments: It is not clearly stated from which parcellation scheme the area Pr1 is adopted, but it is quite possible that it corresponds to area Pr (prorhinal cortex) of VP75, because their map is a classic map for the description of the prorhinal cortex and has the same abbreviation.

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "The cytoarchitectonic features of the prosubiculum are presented in Figs. 1 and 2. The "prosubiculum" was first mentioned by Vogt ('19) as a zone between the CA1 subfield and the subiculum; however, a description of its structure was not provided. Rose ('26) also mentions the prosubiculum, but again no detailed description of the region was given. It was Lorente de No´ ('34) who first described it in detail as a subdivision of the hippocampal formation. …As described by Lorente de No´, the prosubiculum is composed of four layers. …On the basis of only Golgi and Nissl stains, Lorente de No´ hypothesized that the prosubiculum might have its own "distinctive chemical properties" (Lorente de No´, '34, p. 136). Recently Bakst and Amaral ('84), and our own investigations (Moss and Rosene, '88; Rosene and Van Hoesen, '88), provide results consistent with this view. …Taken together the cytoarchitectural and histochemical characteristics of the prosubiculum suggest that it should be considered a distinct subdivision of the hippocampal formation. This is confirmed by the connectivity with the entorhinal and perirhinal cortices described previously (Saunders and Rosene, '88) and with the amygdala as described below." (pp. 188-189, 191)

@InterMapRelations.Comments: It is not stated, from which parcellation scheme areas TF and TH are adopted, but it is quite probable that they correspond to the same areas of BB47, because (i) they have the same abbreviation, (ii) approximately the same location (although both areas with their exact locations are not really described in SRV88), and (iii) the map of BB47 is a classic one for the description of the parahippocampal gyrus.

It is not stated, from which parcellation scheme areas TF and TH are adopted, but it is quite probable that they correspond to the same areas of BB47, because (i) they have the same abbreviation, (ii) approximately the same location (although both areas with their exact locations are not really described in SRV88), and (iii) the map of BB47 is a classic one for the description of the parahippocampal gyrus.

@Methods.Comments: It is said, that the results have been obtained from 46 rhesus monkeys. It is explicitly stated that 36 of these were used for cases with TAA, but it is not mentioned how many of the remaining 10 monkeys have been used for the WGA-HRP and FRT cases, respectively.

@Injections.Citation: "Cortical nucleus. There was one case (case A-12) in which an injection was centered in the posterior part of the cortical nuclei with little involvement of the  deeper but adjacent accessory basal nucleus (see Fig. 7)." (p. 191)

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: " Fiber pathways. The projections of the amygdala to the hippocampal formation followed two different routes. From the accessory basal nucleus and the cortical nuclei labeled fibers coursed medially and caudally in the molecular layer of HATA and the CA1´, CA2, and CA3 subfields of the genu of the hippocampus (Figs. 5, 7), and a few fibers continued through the molecular layer of CA1 to reach the prosubiculum. In contrast, labeled fibers from the medial basal nucleus or the cortical-amygdaloid area (CTA) coursed ventrally into the white matter of the angular bundle between the amygdala and the entorhinal cortex and traveled caudally to enter the alveus and ascend into the prosubiculum (Fig. 6)." (pp. 191, 193)
@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Comments: There is additional information about labeled/affected areas in the description of the corresponding figure.

@Injections.Citation: "There were four cases in which injections of radioactively labeled amino acids were centered in the accessory basal nucleus. The injection site in all cases involved at least one adjacent area: the lateral basal nucleus, the anterior amygdaloid area, the medial nucleus, or the cortical nuclei. In Figures 5 and 8 the results are presented from case A-20, in which an injection of 10 microCi of radioactive amino acids involved primarily the dorsal half or magnocellular part of the accessory basal nucleus." (p. 191)

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: " Fiber pathways. The projections of the amygdala to the hippocampal formation followed two different routes. From the accessory basal nucleus and the cortical nuclei labeled fibers coursed medially and caudally in the molecular layer of HATA and the CA1´, CA2, and CA3 subfields of the genu of the hippocampus (Figs. 5, 7), and a few fibers continued through the molecular layer of CA1 to reach the prosubiculum. In contrast, labeled fibers from the medial basal nucleus or the cortical-amygdaloid area (CTA) coursed ventrally into the white matter of the angular bundle between the amygdala and the entorhinal cortex and traveled caudally to enter the alveus and ascend into the prosubiculum (Fig. 6)." (pp. 191, 193)
@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Comments: There is additional information about labeled/affected areas in the description of the corresponding figure.

@Injections.Citation: "Medial basal nucleus. There were no cases in which an injection of radioactive amino acids was centered in the medial basal nucleus, but this nucleus was involved in many of the cases in which the injection was centered in the lateral basal nucleus or cortical nuclei. In case A-4 (Figs. 6, 8) the injection was centered near the border of the lateral basal nucleus and the medial basal nucleus." (p. 191)

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: " Fiber pathways. The projections of the amygdala to the hippocampal formation followed two different routes. @LabelledSites_Data.Comments: On page 191 it is stated that the molecular layer of area CA1´is divided into stratum radiatum and stratum lacunosum-moleculare. Because of that it is not clear if CA1´ is a four layered area like prosubiculum or a five layered area like CA1.

@Injections.Citation: "Of the three cases in which amino acid injections involved the prosubiculum, only one was centered in the prosubiculum (case H11, Fig. 10), but it also spread into the subiculum, the CA1[1], subfield and the deep layers of TF-TH below the hippocampal formation." (p. 200)

@LabelledSites_Data.Comments: Cases with retrograde injections showed that the prosubiculum does actually not project to the lateral basal nucleus.

@Injections.Citation: "There was only one case in which the injection included the CA1´subfield located in the medial and dorsal part of the genu in the medial and dorsal part of the genu in the rostral part of the hippocampal formation (case H-26, Fig. 11). In other cases at this level with injections involving the more medial hippocampal-amygdaloid transition area (HATA) of the uncus or the more lateral CA3, CA2, CA1 subfields or the more ventral subiculum or presubiculum there was no evidence of label over the amygdala." (p. 200)

@Methods.Comments: It is said, that the results have been obtained from 46 rhesus monkeys. It is explicitly stated that 36 of these were used for cases with TAA, but it is not mentioned how many of the remaining 10 monkeys have been used for the WGA-HRP and FRT cases, respectively.

@Injections.Citation:
"In three other animals a total of eight small and restricted FRT injections were made. In case A-21 three different FRT injections were placed into the amygdala of the left hemisphere and two into the amygdala of the right hemisphere (Figs. 12, 13). In the left hemisphere (case A-21L) one injection was centered in the medial basal nucleus, a second in the CTA and the ventral part of the cortical nuclei, and a third in the CTA and the dorsal part of prorhinal cortex. In the right hemisphere (case A-21R) one injection was centered in the accessory basal nucleus and the other in the lateral basal and accessory basal nuclei.
…In case A-21R (Fig. 13) an injection of FB was centered in the accessory basal nucleus and a smaller injection of DY involved both the accessory basal and the lateral basal nucleus of the amygdala. …In the other hemisphere an injection of FB was placed in the CTA and the ventral part of the cortical nuclei. An injection of DY was centered in the medial basal nucleus and an injection of the latex microspheres (LM) involved both the CTA and the dorsal part of the prorhinal cortex (Figs. 12 and 13, case A-21L)." (p. 200)

"In three other animals a total of eight small and restricted FRT injections were made. (p. 200)

"In case H-32, illustrated in Figure 9, an injection of FB was centered in the molecular layer of subfields CA3, CA2, and CA1, and an injection of DY involved both the molecular layer and the superficial cell layers of the prosubiculum." (pp. 194, 196)

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "Together the retrograde and anterograde data demonstrate two prominent amygdaloid efferent projections to the hippocampal formation. The first originates from the accessory basal and cortical nuclei, which send a strong projection to the molecular layer of the CA3, CA2, and Ca1´ subfields that is most dense in the rostral hippocampal formation and a modest projection to the molecular layer and superficial pyramidal cell layer of the prosubiculum. The second originates from the medial basal nucleus, which sends a strong projection to the prosubiculum.The FRT and HRP-WGA results also established that the cortical-amygdaloid transition area contributes to the amygdaloid projection to the prosubiculum: a result not delineated by the anterograde tracing procedure alone. Both types of experiments indicate that there are probably no amygdaloid projections to the hippocampal formation from the lateral, central, or medial nuclei or the AAA." (pp197, 200)

@Injections.Citation: "In case H-34 (not illustrated), an injection of DY was centered in the subiculum with apparently no spread into the prosubiculum, and in contrast to the prosubiculum injection in case H-32 there were no labeled cells in the amygdala." (p. 197)

publication.title: Comparison of the efferents of the amygdala and the hippocampal formation in the rhesus monkey: II. Reciprocal and non-reciprocal connections
publication.abstract: The pattern of direct connections between the amygdala and the hippocampal formation in the rhesus monkey (Macaca mulatta) was delineated by using both anterograde and retrograde tract-tracing techniques. From the amygdala the accessory basal, medial basal, and the cortical nuclei and the cortical amygdaloid transition area send projections to the hippocampal formation. The efferents from the magnocellular part of the accessory basal nucleus and the cortical nuclei terminate in the molecular layer of subfields CA3, CA2, and CA1', and to a lesser extent in the molecular layer and the superficial part of the pyramidal cell layers of the prosubiculum. In contrast, the projections from the medial basal nucleus and the cortical amygdaloid transition area terminate in the molecular layer and the superficial part of the pyramidal cell layers of the prosubiculum only. From the hippocampal formation, subfield CA1' and the prosubiculum send efferents that terminate in the medial basal nucleus, the cortical transition area, and the ventral part of the cortical nuclei. In addition, the CA1' subfield projects to the ventral, parvicellular part of the accessory basal nucleus. The present data emphasize an important role for the prosubiculum and the CA1' subfield in medial temporal lobe area connections. Both regions, in addition to supporting direct connections between the amygdala and the hippocampal formation, also have extensive connections with the entorhinal cortex. As for the amygdala, the accessory basal nucleus sends efferents to both the hippocampal formation and the entorhinal cortex. The data demonstrate an anatomical means by which the amygdala, hippocampal formation, and the entorhinal cortex may interact. It is proposed that these connections may be important in the limbic memory system.
